text:
Hello! I am a frontend developer from Kharkiv (Ukraine). I contribute to open source projects and work on my own framework called Rete.js. <http://rete.js.org>

I started learning programming more than 5 years ago, studied languages ​​ PHP -> JS -> C++ -> C# -> Java -> ES6/TS. Now basically I programming on JavaScript.

At the moment I see the benefit for myself in languages ​​such as JS/TS and C++, but one of the problems still remains - writing the code. Perhaps someone will argue that you need to have a good knowledge  of programming language. I agree, good knowledge will allow you to write quality code, but there are problems with reading someone else's code that is written in a different style (or has poor quality).

Being inspired by UE4, Substance Designer and Plant factory I decided to write my own library for creating such editors in the browser (dataflow programming). At that time (as now) I didn’t find a universal and customizable framework/library. I have started writing a library called D3-Node-Editor (March, 2017) and after a year of development I revised many approaches and rewrote it to the new architecture and called Rete.js. <https://github.com/retejs/rete>

Are there somebody who have experience in Dataflow programming and know the current unsolved problems? I'm going to postgraduate studies to working with dataflow and my framework, but my scientific director (I hope I correctly translated to english phrase "научный руководитель") says that a dissertation must contains scientific novelty, and framework is only a tool. So I am not sure whether to continue studying at the university in order to do this, since among professors no one has much experience with visual programming.

elements.text: Hello! I am a frontend developer from Kharkiv (Ukraine). I contribute to open source projects and work on my own framework called Rete.js.

I started learning programming more than 5 years ago, studied languages ​​ PHP -> JS -> C++ -> C# -> Java -> ES6/TS. Now basically I programming on JavaScript.

At the moment I see the benefit for myself in languages ​​such as JS/TS and C++, but one of the problems still remains - writing the code. Perhaps someone will argue that you need to have a good knowledge  of programming language. I agree, good knowledge will allow you to write quality code, but there are problems with reading someone else's code that is written in a different style (or has poor quality).

Being inspired by UE4, Substance Designer and Plant factory I decided to write my own library for creating such editors in the browser (dataflow programming). At that time (as now) I didn’t find a universal and customizable framework/library. I have started writing a library called D3-Node-Editor (March, 2017) and after a year of development I revised many approaches and rewrote it to the new architecture and called Rete.js.

Are there somebody who have experience in Dataflow programming and know the current unsolved problems? I'm going to postgraduate studies to working with dataflow and my framework, but my scientific director (I hope I correctly translated to english phrase "научный руководитель") says that a dissertation must contains scientific novelty, and framework is only a tool. So I am not sure whether to continue studying at the university in order to do this, since among professors no one has much experience with visual programming.

text: You have come to a good place <@UD98CHSLS>.  Cannot sat that I'm up to date, but I have some dataflow adjacent interests with Propagator Networks <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O3tVctB_VSU> and Bidirectional Transformations <http://bx-community.wikidot.com/bx2019:home>.  (People tell me it's best to have professors whose interests are in the same ballpark as one's own.  I wasn't so lucky myself.)  Are you more interested in the interface design of node-based tools or are you interested more interested in theory?

.  (People tell me it's best to have professors whose interests are in the same ballpark as one's own.  I wasn't so lucky myself.)  Are you more interested in the interface design of node-based tools or are you interested more interested in theory?

text: I think there's a lot of promise in both directions.  Though I think academics often favor the theoretical, actually because they do, there's even more room to do cool things with interfaces.

elements.text: I think there's a lot of promise in both directions.  Though I think academics often favor the theoretical, actually because they do, there's even more room to do cool things with interfaces.

text: On the real mathy side, I've been following John Baez <https://johncarlosbaez.wordpress.com/2018/09/18/what-is-applied-category-theory/>.

attachments.title: What is Applied Category Theory?
attachments.text:
Tai-Danae Bradley has a new free “booklet” on applied category theory.  It was inspired by the workshop Applied Category Theory 2018, which she attended, and I think it makes a great complement to Fong and Spivak’s book Seven Sketches and my online course based on that book:
• Tai-Danae Bradley, What is Applied Category Theory?

  Abstract. This is a collection of introductory, expository notes on applied category theory, inspired by the 2018 Applied Category Theory Workshop, and in these notes we take a leisurely stroll through two themes (functorial semantics and compositionality), two constructions (monoidal categories and decorated cospans) and two examples (chemical reaction networks and natural language processing) within the field.

Check it out!
attachments.fallback: Azimuth Link: What is Applied Category Theory?

elements.text: On the real mathy side, I've been following John Baez

text: On the interface side, oh man, I don't know.  Neos is a gloriously hackitily beautiful.  <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LKxSUrV1cR4>

elements.text: On the interface side, oh man, I don't know.  Neos is a gloriously hackitily beautiful.

text: Click around there and you will see some weird stuff.  One of my VR shocks has been just how much more space there is to put interface elements.

elements.text: Click around there and you will see some weird stuff.  One of my VR shocks has been just how much more space there is to put interface elements.

text: For example, with the right affordances, navigating graphs with thousands and tens of thousands of nodes is like a walk in the park.

elements.text: For example, with the right affordances, navigating graphs with thousands and tens of thousands of nodes is like a walk in the park.

text: I totally, would have not thought this when I was starting.
